verses.name: Song of Songs 1:1
verses.text: Solomon's Song of Songs.

verses.name: Song of Songs 1:2
verses.text: Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth- for your love is more delightful than wine.

verses.name: Song of Songs 1:3
verses.text: Pleasing is the fragrance of your perfumes; your name is like perfume poured out. No wonder the maidens love you!

verses.name: Song of Songs 1:4
verses.text: Take me away with you-let us hurry! Let the king bring me into his chambers. We rejoice and delight in you; we will praise your love more than wine. How right they are to adore you!

verses.name: Song of Songs 1:5
verses.text: Dark am I, yet lovely, O daughters of Jerusalem, dark like the tents of Kedar, like the tent curtains of Solomon.

verses.name: Song of Songs 1:6
verses.text: Do not stare at me because I am dark, because I am darkened by the sun. My mother's sons were angry with me and made me take care of the vineyards; my own vineyard I have neglected.

verses.name: Song of Songs 1:7
verses.text: Tell me, you whom I love, where you graze your flock and where you rest your sheep at midday. Why should I be like a veiled woman beside the flocks of your friends?

verses.name: Song of Songs 1:8
verses.text: If you do not know, most beautiful of women, follow the tracks of the sheep and graze your young goats by the tents of the shepherds.

verses.name: Song of Songs 1:9
verses.text: I liken you, my darling, to a mare harnessed to one of the chariots of Pharaoh.

verses.name: Song of Songs 1:10
verses.text: Your cheeks are beautiful with earrings, your neck with strings of jewels.

verses.name: Song of Songs 1:11
verses.text: We will make you earrings of gold, studded with silver.

verses.name: Song of Songs 1:12
verses.text: While the king was at his table, my perfume spread its fragrance.

verses.name: Song of Songs 1:13
verses.text: My lover is to me a sachet of myrrh resting between my breasts.

verses.name: Song of Songs 1:14
verses.text: My lover is to me a cluster of henna blossoms from the vineyards of En Gedi.

verses.name: Song of Songs 1:15
verses.text: How beautiful you are, my darling! Oh, how beautiful! Your eyes are doves.

verses.name: Song of Songs 1:16
verses.text: How handsome you are, my lover! Oh, how charming! And our bed is verdant.

verses.name: Song of Songs 1:17
verses.text: The beams of our house are cedars; our rafters are firs.

verses.name: Song of Songs 2:1
verses.text: I am a rose of Sharon, a lily of the valleys.

verses.name: Song of Songs 2:2
verses.text: Like a lily among thorns is my darling among the maidens.

verses.name: Song of Songs 2:3
verses.text: Like an apple tree among the trees of the forest is my lover among the young men. I delight to sit in his shade, and his fruit is sweet to my taste.

verses.name: Song of Songs 2:4
verses.text: He has taken me to the banquet hall, and his banner over me is love.

verses.name: Song of Songs 2:5
verses.text: Strengthen me with raisins, refresh me with apples, for I am faint with love.

verses.name: Song of Songs 2:6
verses.text: His left arm is under my head, and his right arm embraces me.

verses.name: Song of Songs 2:7
verses.text: Daughters of Jerusalem, I charge you by the gazelles and by the does of the field: Do not arouse or awaken love until it so desires.

verses.name: Song of Songs 2:8
verses.text: Listen! My lover! Look! Here he comes, leaping across the mountains, bounding over the hills.

verses.name: Song of Songs 2:9
verses.text: My lover is like a gazelle or a young stag. Look! There he stands behind our wall, gazing through the windows, peering through the lattice.

verses.name: Song of Songs 2:10
verses.text: My lover spoke and said to me, "Arise, my darling, my beautiful one, and come with me.

verses.name: Song of Songs 2:11
verses.text: See! The winter is past; the rains are over and gone.

verses.name: Song of Songs 2:12
verses.text: Flowers appear on the earth; the season of singing has come, the cooing of doves is heard in our land.

verses.name: Song of Songs 2:13
verses.text: The fig tree forms its early fruit; the blossoming vines spread their fragrance. Arise, come, my darling; my beautiful one, come with me."

verses.name: Song of Songs 2:14
verses.text: My dove in the clefts of the rock, in the hiding places on the mountainside, show me your face, let me hear your voice; for your voice is sweet, and your face is lovely.

verses.name: Song of Songs 2:15
verses.text: Catch for us the foxes, the little foxes that ruin the vineyards, our vineyards that are in bloom.

verses.name: Song of Songs 2:16
verses.text: My lover is mine and I am his; he browses among the lilies.

verses.name: Song of Songs 2:17
verses.text: Until the day breaks and the shadows flee, turn, my lover, and be like a gazelle or like a young stag on the rugged hills.

verses.name: Song of Songs 3:1
verses.text: All night long on my bed I looked for the one my heart loves; I looked for him but did not find him.

verses.name: Song of Songs 3:2
verses.text: I will get up now and go about the city, through its streets and squares; I will search for the one my heart loves. So I looked for him but did not find him.

verses.name: Song of Songs 3:3
verses.text: The watchmen found me as they made their rounds in the city. "Have you seen the one my heart loves?"

verses.name: Song of Songs 3:4
verses.text: Scarcely had I passed them when I found the one my heart loves. I held him and would not let him go till I had brought him to my mother's house, to the room of the one who conceived me.

verses.name: Song of Songs 3:5
verses.text: Daughters of Jerusalem, I charge you by the gazelles and by the does of the field: Do not arouse or awaken love until it so desires.

verses.name: Song of Songs 3:6
verses.text: Who is this coming up from the desert like a column of smoke, perfumed with myrrh and incense made from all the spices of the merchant?

verses.name: Song of Songs 3:7
verses.text: Look! It is Solomon's carriage, escorted by sixty warriors, the noblest of Israel,

verses.name: Song of Songs 3:8
verses.text: all of them wearing the sword, all experienced in battle, each with his sword at his side, prepared for the terrors of the night.

verses.name: Song of Songs 3:9
verses.text: King Solomon made for himself the carriage; he made it of wood from Lebanon.

verses.name: Song of Songs 3:10
verses.text: Its posts he made of silver, its base of gold. Its seat was upholstered with purple, its interior lovingly inlaid by the daughters of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Song of Songs 3:11
verses.text: Come out, you daughters of Zion, and look at King Solomon wearing the crown, the crown with which his mother crowned him on the day of his wedding, the day his heart rejoiced.

verses.name: Song of Songs 4:1
verses.text: How beautiful you are, my darling! Oh, how beautiful! Your eyes behind your veil are doves. Your hair is like a flock of goats descending from Mount Gilead.

verses.name: Song of Songs 4:2
verses.text: Your teeth are like a flock of sheep just shorn, coming up from the washing. Each has its twin; not one of them is alone.

verses.name: Song of Songs 4:3
verses.text: Your lips are like a scarlet ribbon; your mouth is lovely. Your temples behind your veil are like the halves of a pomegranate.

verses.name: Song of Songs 4:4
verses.text: Your neck is like the tower of David, built with elegance; on it hang a thousand shields, all of them shields of warriors.

verses.name: Song of Songs 4:5
verses.text: Your two breasts are like two fawns, like twin fawns of a gazelle that browse among the lilies.

verses.name: Song of Songs 4:6
verses.text: Until the day breaks and the shadows flee, I will go to the mountain of myrrh and to the hill of incense.

verses.name: Song of Songs 4:7
verses.text: All beautiful you are, my darling; there is no flaw in you.

verses.name: Song of Songs 4:8
verses.text: Come with me from Lebanon, my bride, come with me from Lebanon. Descend from the crest of Amana, from the top of Senir, the summit of Hermon, from the lions' dens and the mountain haunts of the leopards.

verses.name: Song of Songs 4:9
verses.text: You have stolen my heart, my sister, my bride; you have stolen my heart with one glance of your eyes, with one jewel of your necklace.

verses.name: Song of Songs 4:10
verses.text: How delightful is your love, my sister, my bride! How much more pleasing is your love than wine, and the fragrance of your perfume than any spice!

verses.name: Song of Songs 4:11
verses.text: Your lips drop sweetness as the honeycomb, my bride; milk and honey are under your tongue. The fragrance of your garments is like that of Lebanon.

verses.name: Song of Songs 4:12
verses.text: You are a garden locked up, my sister, my bride; you are a spring enclosed, a sealed fountain.

verses.name: Song of Songs 4:13
verses.text: Your plants are an orchard of pomegranates with choice fruits, with henna and nard,

verses.name: Song of Songs 4:14
verses.text: nard and saffron, calamus and cinnamon, with every kind of incense tree, with myrrh and aloes and all the finest spices.

verses.name: Song of Songs 4:15
verses.text: You are a garden fountain, a well of flowing water streaming down from Lebanon.

verses.name: Song of Songs 4:16
verses.text: Awake, north wind, and come, south wind! Blow on my garden, that its fragrance may spread abroad. Let my lover come into his garden and taste its choice fruits.

verses.name: Song of Songs 5:1
verses.text: I have come into my garden, my sister, my bride; I have gathered my myrrh with my spice. I have eaten my honeycomb and my honey; I have drunk my wine and my milk. Eat, O friends, and drink; drink your fill, O lovers.

verses.name: Song of Songs 5:2
verses.text: I slept but my heart was awake. Listen! My lover is knocking: "Open to me, my sister, my darling, my dove, my flawless one. My head is drenched with dew, my hair with the dampness of the night."

verses.name: Song of Songs 5:3
verses.text: I have taken off my robe- must I put it on again? I have washed my feet- must I soil them again?

verses.name: Song of Songs 5:4
verses.text: My lover thrust his hand through the latch-opening; my heart began to pound for him.

verses.name: Song of Songs 5:5
verses.text: I arose to open for my lover, and my hands dripped with myrrh, my fingers with flowing myrrh, on the handles of the lock.

verses.name: Song of Songs 5:6
verses.text: I opened for my lover, but my lover had left; he was gone. My heart sank at his departure. I looked for him but did not find him. I called him but he did not answer.

verses.name: Song of Songs 5:7
verses.text: The watchmen found me as they made their rounds in the city. They beat me, they bruised me; they took away my cloak, those watchmen of the walls!

verses.name: Song of Songs 5:8
verses.text: O daughters of Jerusalem, I charge you- if you find my lover, what will you tell him? Tell him I am faint with love.

verses.name: Song of Songs 5:9
verses.text: How is your beloved better than others, most beautiful of women? How is your beloved better than others, that you charge us so?

verses.name: Song of Songs 5:10
verses.text: My lover is radiant and ruddy, outstanding among ten thousand.

verses.name: Song of Songs 5:11
verses.text: His head is purest gold; his hair is wavy and black as a raven.

verses.name: Song of Songs 5:12
verses.text: His eyes are like doves by the water streams, washed in milk, mounted like jewels.

verses.name: Song of Songs 5:13
verses.text: His cheeks are like beds of spice yielding perfume. His lips are like lilies dripping with myrrh.

verses.name: Song of Songs 5:14
verses.text: His arms are rods of gold set with chrysolite. His body is like polished ivory decorated with sapphires.

verses.name: Song of Songs 5:15
verses.text: His legs are pillars of marble set on bases of pure gold. His appearance is like Lebanon, choice as its cedars.

verses.name: Song of Songs 5:16
verses.text: His mouth is sweetness itself; he is altogether lovely. This is my lover, this my friend, O daughters of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Song of Songs 6:1
verses.text: Where has your lover gone, most beautiful of women? Which way did your lover turn, that we may look for him with you?

verses.name: Song of Songs 6:2
verses.text: My lover has gone down to his garden, to the beds of spices, to browse in the gardens and to gather lilies.

verses.name: Song of Songs 6:3
verses.text: I am my lover's and my lover is mine; he browses among the lilies.

verses.name: Song of Songs 6:4
verses.text: You are beautiful, my darling, as Tirzah, lovely as Jerusalem, majestic as troops with banners.

verses.name: Song of Songs 6:5
verses.text: Turn your eyes from me; they overwhelm me. Your hair is like a flock of goats descending from Gilead.

verses.name: Song of Songs 6:6
verses.text: Your teeth are like a flock of sheep coming up from the washing. Each has its twin, not one of them is alone.

verses.name: Song of Songs 6:7
verses.text: Your temples behind your veil are like the halves of a pomegranate.

verses.name: Song of Songs 6:8
verses.text: Sixty queens there may be, and eighty concubines, and virgins beyond number;

verses.name: Song of Songs 6:9
verses.text: but my dove, my perfect one, is unique, the only daughter of her mother, the favorite of the one who bore her. The maidens saw her and called her blessed; the queens and concubines praised her.

verses.name: Song of Songs 6:10
verses.text: Who is this that appears like the dawn, fair as the moon, bright as the sun, majestic as the stars in procession?

verses.name: Song of Songs 6:11
verses.text: I went down to the grove of nut trees to look at the new growth in the valley, to see if the vines had budded or the pomegranates were in bloom.

verses.name: Song of Songs 6:12
verses.text: Before I realized it, my desire set me among the royal chariots of my people.

verses.name: Song of Songs 6:13
verses.text: Come back, come back, O Shulammite; come back, come back, that we may gaze on you! Why would you gaze on the Shulammite as on the dance of Mahanaim?

verses.name: Song of Songs 7:1
verses.text: How beautiful your sandaled feet, O prince's daughter! Your graceful legs are like jewels, the work of a craftsman's hands.

verses.name: Song of Songs 7:2
verses.text: Your navel is a rounded goblet that never lacks blended wine. Your waist is a mound of wheat encircled by lilies.

verses.name: Song of Songs 7:3
verses.text: Your breasts are like two fawns, twins of a gazelle.

verses.name: Song of Songs 7:4
verses.text: Your neck is like an ivory tower. Your eyes are the pools of Heshbon by the gate of Bath Rabbim. Your nose is like the tower of Lebanon looking toward Damascus.

verses.name: Song of Songs 7:5
verses.text: Your head crowns you like Mount Carmel. Your hair is like royal tapestry; the king is held captive by its tresses.

verses.name: Song of Songs 7:6
verses.text: How beautiful you are and how pleasing, O love, with your delights!

verses.name: Song of Songs 7:7
verses.text: Your stature is like that of the palm, and your breasts like clusters of fruit.

verses.name: Song of Songs 7:8
verses.text: I said, "I will climb the palm tree; I will take hold of its fruit." May your breasts be like the clusters of the vine, the fragrance of your breath like apples,

verses.name: Song of Songs 7:9
verses.text: and your mouth like the best wine. May the wine go straight to my lover, flowing gently over lips and teeth.

verses.name: Song of Songs 7:10
verses.text: I belong to my lover, and his desire is for me.

verses.name: Song of Songs 7:11
verses.text: Come, my lover, let us go to the countryside, let us spend the night in the villages.

verses.name: Song of Songs 7:12
verses.text: Let us go early to the vineyards to see if the vines have budded, if their blossoms have opened, and if the pomegranates are in bloom- there I will give you my love.

verses.name: Song of Songs 7:13
verses.text: The mandrakes send out their fragrance, and at our door is every delicacy, both new and old, that I have stored up for you, my lover.

verses.name: Song of Songs 8:1
verses.text: If only you were to me like a brother, who was nursed at my mother's breasts! Then, if I found you outside, I would kiss you, and no one would despise me.

verses.name: Song of Songs 8:2
verses.text: I would lead you and bring you to my mother's house- she who has taught me. I would give you spiced wine to drink, the nectar of my pomegranates.

verses.name: Song of Songs 8:3
verses.text: His left arm is under my head and his right arm embraces me.

verses.name: Song of Songs 8:4
verses.text: Daughters of Jerusalem, I charge you: Do not arouse or awaken love until it so desires.

verses.name: Song of Songs 8:5
verses.text: Who is this coming up from the desert leaning on her lover? Under the apple tree I roused you; there your mother conceived you, there she who was in labor gave you birth.

verses.name: Song of Songs 8:6
verses.text: Place me like a seal over your heart, like a seal on your arm; for love is as strong as death, its jealousy unyielding as the grave. It burns like blazing fire, like a mighty flame.

verses.name: Song of Songs 8:7
verses.text: Many waters cannot quench love; rivers cannot wash it away. If one were to give all the wealth of his house for love, it would be utterly scorned.

verses.name: Song of Songs 8:8
verses.text: We have a young sister, and her breasts are not yet grown. What shall we do for our sister for the day she is spoken for?

verses.name: Song of Songs 8:9
verses.text: If she is a wall, we will build towers of silver on her. If she is a door, we will enclose her with panels of cedar.

verses.name: Song of Songs 8:10
verses.text: I am a wall, and my breasts are like towers. Thus I have become in his eyes like one bringing contentment.

verses.name: Song of Songs 8:11
verses.text: Solomon had a vineyard in Baal Hamon; he let out his vineyard to tenants. Each was to bring for its fruit a thousand shekels of silver.

verses.name: Song of Songs 8:12
verses.text: But my own vineyard is mine to give; the thousand shekels are for you, O Solomon, and two hundred are for those who tend its fruit.

verses.name: Song of Songs 8:13
verses.text: You who dwell in the gardens with friends in attendance, let me hear your voice!

verses.name: Song of Songs 8:14
verses.text: Come away, my lover, and be like a gazelle or like a young stag on the spice-laden mountains.
